dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, diving into the aviation industry, the numbers are, like, pretty staggering, right? We're talking over a third of the global passenger plane fleet, that's 8,500 planes, just... parked.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, diving into the aviation industry, the numbers are, like, pretty staggering, right? We're talking over a third of the global passenger plane fleet, that's eight thousand, five hundred planes, just parked.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild. And, uh, if you look at scheduled flights this week, it's less than half the total seats we had back in mid-January. I mean, it's a ghost town out there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild. And, uh, if you look at scheduled flights this week, it's less than half the total seats we had back in mid-January. I mean, it's a ghost town out there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And the big takeaway from industry watchers is that it's not a quick fix. We're looking at *years* for airlines to get back to their pre-pandemic size.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And the big takeaway from industry watchers is that it's not a quick fix. We're looking at years for airlines to get back to their pre-pandemic size.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the coronavirus pandemic ends, many industry watchers now expect it will take years for airlines to return to their former size.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Years, yeah. Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, he's estimating airlines will need, like, 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, which sounds like a lot, but it's 2,000 *fewer* than he predicted just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Years, yeah. Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, he's estimating airlines will need, like, six thousand, three hundred new aircraft over the next five years, which sounds like a lot, but it's two thousand fewer than he predicted just a few months ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Two thousand fewer! And that's based on a stomach-churning 60% reduction in passenger miles *this year*. I mean, that's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two thousand fewer! And that's based on a stomach-churning sixty percent reduction in passenger miles this year. I mean, that's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it gets worse, uh, Helane Becker from Cowen, she thinks it'll take 24 to 30 months just for traffic to get back to *some* level of normal. She even compared it to 9/11; it took, like, seven years for US airline traffic to fully recover on longer flights back then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it gets worse, uh, Helane Becker from Cowen, she thinks it'll take twenty four to thirty months just for traffic to get back to some level of normal. She even compared it to nine over eleven; it took, like, seven years for U S airline traffic to fully recover on longer flights back then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cowen airline analyst Helane Becker told Forbes she expects it will take 18 to 24 months for traffic to return to some level of normal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, less demand for flights means less demand for planes. Boeing, obviously, is feeling that. They're actually seeking an $80 billion bailout for the US aerospace industry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, less demand for flights means less demand for planes. Boeing, obviously, is feeling that. They're actually seeking an eighty billion dollar bailout for the U S aerospace industry.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing Seeks $60 Billion Bailout For U.S. Aerospace Boeing called for at least $60 billion in financial support for U.S. aerosp...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that makes sense, given the projections. Stallard, again, he's saying the active airline fleet won't return to 2019 levels until around 2026.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that makes sense, given the projections. Stallard, again, he's saying the active airline fleet won't return to twenty nineteen levels until around twenty twenty six.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stallard believes the active airline fleet wont return to 2019 levels until about 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so Airbus deliveries, he's got those down 26% from previous forecasts, and Boeing's down even more, like, 30%. That's hundreds of planes for each manufacturer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so Airbus deliveries, he's got those down twenty six percent from previous forecasts, and Boeing's down even more, like, thirty percent. That's hundreds of planes for each manufacturer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He expects Airbus deliveries will come in 21% lower than hed previously forecast from 2020 through 2024, off 1,012 planes, while Boeing's will be down 26%, or 931 planes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's hitting different types of planes differently too, right? Like, widebodies, which are used for international routes, they're seeing the steepest fall-off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's hitting different types of planes differently too, right? Like, widebodies, which are used for international routes, they're seeing the steepest fall-off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He sees demand being hit proportionately harder for the widebodies used on international routes, which are seeing the steepest fall-off in flying...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But Airbus has, like, the A321, which is a popular narrowbody, giving them a bit of a cushion. Boeing, on the other hand, still has the 737 MAX issues compounding their problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But Airbus has, like, the A321, which is a popular narrowbody, giving them a bit of a cushion. Boeing, on the other hand, still has the seven hundred thirty seven meters A X issues compounding their problems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aboulafia and Stallard expect Airbus to be cushioned by the popularity of the A321, a long-range narrowbody... in Boeings, because of the grounding of the troubled 737 MAX.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is, uh, just terrible timing. But hey, governments are stepping in, which is good, right? Like, the US and European governments are lining up financial support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, just terrible timing. But hey, governments are stepping in, which is good, right? Like, the U S and European governments are lining up financial support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. and European governments are also lining up to provide financial support that will keep factories open and producing planes that the market doesnt really want right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a double-edged sword, though, Host_B. Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group, he put it well, saying you're "pulling demand forward to a certain extent," but it probably beats falling off a cliff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a double-edged sword, though, Host B. Richard Aboulafia from Teal Group, he put it well, saying you're pulling demand forward to a certain extent, but it probably beats falling off a cliff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Youre pulling demand forward to a certain extent, but it probably beats falling off a cliff, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then there's the string attached, like, Boeing's CEO, David Calhoun, said he wouldn't take federal assistance if it meant surrendering equity or having to maintain 90% of their headcount.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then there's the string attached, like, Boeing's C E O, David Calhoun, said he wouldn't take federal assistance if it meant surrendering equity or having to maintain ninety percent of their headcount.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing CEO David Calhoun said last week that he wouldnt take federal assistance if it required surrendering equity to the government. Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a really complex situation. I mean, everyone agrees production needs to be cut, headcount needs to be cut, but they also need support to keep some level of production going.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a really complex situation. I mean, everyone agrees production needs to be cut, headcount needs to be cut, but they also need support to keep some level of production going.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both sides need to find a way production can be cut, employee head count can be cut, but some sort of support can be found for keeping production higher than actual short-term market needs, which are approaching zero, says Aboulafia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, uh, a lot of unknowns. Aboulafia actually mentioned, and I quote, "I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, uh, a lot of unknowns. Aboulafia actually mentioned, and I quote, I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I think a lot of us have a creeping anxiety it could be a whole lot worse, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that's the scary part. We don't know the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond, or even how effective government efforts will actually be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's the scary part. We don't know the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond, or even how effective government efforts will actually be.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...given the many unknowns as to the length of the pandemic, how travelers will respond and the effectiveness of government efforts to support airlines, manufactures and the global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a massive, um, economic and logistical puzzle, and aviation is right at the heart of it.
